Award.AwardTitle: CRPA NSF Collaborative Research: The Ultimate Cosmic Experiment-Chemistry Labs at the Far Edges of the Universe

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This CRPA award addresses the exciting contemporary chemical science that occurs in interstellar space. The new interferometers coming online this year will enhance this new area of science and further intrigue those who engage. The plan in this award is to build an exhibit that will interest the audience with the space-based aspects, but will also engage them in understanding the chemistry that occurs in space. This is a collaborative effort between the University of Virginia and the Harvard-Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory.

The exhibit is relatively small facilitating its mobility. Thus, the authors will travel the exhibit to smaller venues in rural areas and embrace citizens who are typically under-served by educational opportunities of ISE venues. The target audience is 12-15 year old youths.

Clearly, this project is meant to engage the public in both Space science and Chemistry with the ultimate hope that some individuals will even think about careers in the joint science field that is emerging from these types of behaviors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The “Cosmic Chemistry: Discovering Molecules in Space” Educators Guide was developed by science educators at the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory. This project was in collaboration with the creation of a small traveling museum exhibition of the same name by the University of Virginia, via a collaborative Communicating Research to Public Audiences NSF award. The exhibit and accompanying Educators Guide of hands-on activities introduce students, educators, and public audiences to essential concepts of chemistry including molecular structure and chemical analysis, through the topic of interstellar chemistry. Also known as “astrochemistry,” this emerging area of interdisciplinary scientific research is revolutionizing our understanding of the chemistry involved in the formation of stars, planets, our own solar system, and even Earth. The exhibit communicates information about new NSF-funded facilities for radio astronomy, the Expanded Very Large Array and the Atacama Large Millimeter Array. The project takes advantage of the public appeal of space science to attract attention and interest to chemistry. The target audience for the Educators Guide is teachers of students in the 12-15 year old age range, a critical period for career choices in STEM fields. The evidence-based materials of this project provide a model for educators and for students of how current science can be integrated into educational experiences that support the learning of important STEM Disciplinary Core Ideas, Science Practices, and Cross-Cutting Concepts in science.

 

Broader Impact: The Cosmic Chemistry exhibit and Educators Guide will reach tens of thousands of students and their teachers who visit the National Radio Astronomy Observatory in Green Bank, West Virginia. The exhibit is intended to travel and the Educators Guide will be disseminated via the collaborators’ astronomy education networks to teachers nationwide who can use the activities independently of the Cosmic Chemistry exhibit.
